					<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading mw-first-heading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Kashmiri language</span></h1>
							
<div id="p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown mw-portlet mw-portlet-lang"  >
	<input type="checkbox" id="p-lang-btn-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox mw-interlanguage-selector" aria-label="Go to an article in another language. Available in 100 languages"   >
	<label id="p-lang-btn-label" for="p-lang-btn-checkbox" class="vector-dropdown-label cdx-button cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--weight-quiet cdx-button--action-progressive mw-portlet-lang-heading-100" aria-hidden="true"  ><span class="vector-icon mw-ui-icon-language-progressive mw-ui-icon-wikimedia-language-progressive"></span>

<span class="vector-dropdown-label-text">100 languages</span>
	</label>
	<div class="vector-dropdown-content">

		<div class="vector-menu-content">
			
			<ul class="vector-menu-content-list">

href="https://awa.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E0%A4%95%E0%A4%B6%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%AE%E0%A5%80%E0%A4%B0%E0%A5%80" title="कश्मीरी – Awadhi" lang="awa" hreflang="awa" &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">كٲشُر</span></li><li>कॉशुर</li><li><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1009416381">.mw-parser-output .script-Shrd{font-family:"Noto Sans Sharada"}</style><span class="script-Shrd" style="font-size:16px; line-height:2.1em;">𑆑𑆳𑆯𑆶𑆫𑇀</span></li></ul></div></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="infobox-image"><span class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Frameless"><a href="/wiki/File:Kashmiri_language.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Kashmiri_language.png/200px-Kashmiri_language.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="174" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Kashmiri_language.png/300px-Kashmiri_language.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Kashmiri_language.png/400px-Kashmiri_language.png 2x" data-file-width="536" data-file-height="465" /></a></span><div class="infobox-caption" style="padding:0.35em 0.35em 0.25em;line-height:1.25em;">The word "Koshur" in <a href="/wiki/Perso-Arabic_script" class="mw-redirect" title="Perso-Arabic script">Perso-Arabic script</a> (contemporary, official status), <a href="/wiki/Sharada_script" title="Sharada script">Sharada script</a> (ancient, liturgical) and <a href="/wiki/Devanagari" title="Devanagari">Devanagari</a></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">Native&#160;to</th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;"><a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">Region</th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;"><a href="/wiki/Kashmir" title="Kashmir">Kashmir</a> (<a href="/wiki/Kashmir_division" title="Kashmir division">Kashmir division</a> and parts of <a href="/wiki/Chenab_valley" class="mw-redirect" title="Chenab valley">Chenab valley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(union_territory)" title="Jammu and Kashmir (union territory)">Jammu and Kashmir</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-e26_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-e26-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> parts of northern <a href="/wiki/Azad_Kashmir" title="Azad Kashmir">Azad Kashmir</a>)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">Ethnicity</th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;"><a href="/wiki/Kashmiris" title="Kashmiris">Kashmiris</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;"><div style="display: inline-block; line-height: 1.2em; padding: .1em 0;">Native speakers</div></th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;">7.1 million&#160;(2011)<sup id="cite_ref-e26_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-e26-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;"><div style="display: inline-block; line-height: 1.2em; padding: .1em 0;"><span class="wrap"><a href="/wiki/Language_family" title="Language family">Language family</a></span></div></th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;"><div style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Indo-European_languages" title="Indo-European languages">Indo-European</a>
<ul style="line-height:100%; margin-left:1.35em;padding-left:0"><li>
<a href="/wiki/Indo-Iranian_languages" title="Indo-Iranian languages">Indo-Iranian</a><ul style="line-height:100%;margin-left:0.45em;padding-left:0;"><li><a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_languages" title="Indo-Aryan languages">Indo-Aryan</a><ul style="line-height:100%;margin-left:0.45em;padding-left:0;"><li><a href="/wiki/Dardic_languages" title="Dardic languages">Dardic</a><ul style="line-height:100%;margin-left:0.45em;padding-left:0;"><li>Eastern Dardic<ul style="line-height:100%;margin-left:0.45em;padding-left:0;"><li>Kashmiric<ul style="line-height:100%;margin-left:0.45em;padding-left:0;"><li><b>Kashmiri</b></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></div></td></tr><tr class="plainlist"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;">Dialects</th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Kishtwari" title="Kishtwari">Kishtwari</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poguli" class="mw-redirect" title="Poguli">Poguli</a><sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>
</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label" style="white-space:nowrap;padding-right:0.65em;"><div style="display: inline-block; line-height: 1.2em; padding: .1em 0;"><span class="wrap"><a href="/wiki/Writing_system" title="Writing system">Writing system</a></span></div></th><td class="infobox-data" style="line-height:1.3em;">Official: <a href="/wiki/Perso-Arabic_script" class="mw-redirect" title="Perso-Arabic script">Perso-Arabic script</a> (contemporary)<sup id="cite_ref-Mouton_de_Gruyter_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mouton_de_Gruyter-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup><br />Others: <a href="/wiki/Devanagari" title="Devanagari">Devanagari</a><sup id="cite_ref-Mouton_de_Gruyter_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mouton_de_Gruyter-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> (informally used by some sections within the <a href="/wiki/Kashmiri_Pandit" class="mw-redirect" title="Kashmiri Pandit">Kashmiri Pandit</a> community after 1990),<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup><br /><a href="/wiki/Sharada_script" title="Sharada script">Sharada script</a> (ancient/liturgical)<sup id="cite_ref-Mouton_de_Gruyter_4-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mouton_de_Gruyter-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" class="infobox-header" style="color: black; <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1134653256">.mw-parser-output .side-box{margin:4px 0;box-sizing:border-box;border:1px solid #aaa;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em;background-color:#f9f9f9;display:flow-root}.mw-parser-output .side-box-abovebelow,.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{padding:0.25em 0.9em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-image{padding:2px 0 2px 0.9em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-imageright{padding:2px 0.9em 2px 0;text-align:center}@media(min-width:500px){.mw-parser-output .side-box-flex{display:flex;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{flex:1}}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .side-box{width:238px}.mw-parser-output .side-box-right{clear:right;float:right;margin-left:1em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-left{margin-right:1em}}</style><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1092331828">@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .contains-special-characters{width:22em}}</style><div class="side-box metadata side-box-right contains-special-characters noprint selfref"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409">
<div class="side-box-flex">
<div class="side-box-image"><span typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Example.of.complex.text.rendering.svg/40px-Example.of.complex.text.rendering.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="19" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Example.of.complex.text.rendering.svg/60px-Example.of.complex.text.rendering.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Example.of.complex.text.rendering.svg/80px-Example.of.complex.text.rendering.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="58" data-file-height="28" /></span></span></div>
<div class="side-box-text plainlist"><b>This article contains <a href="/wiki/Brahmic_scripts" title="Brahmic scripts">Indic text</a>.</b> Without proper <a href="/wiki/Help:Multilingual_support_(Indic)" title="Help:Multilingual support (Indic)">rendering support</a>, you may see <a href="/wiki/Mojibake" title="Mojibake">question marks or boxes</a>, misplaced vowels or missing conjuncts&#32;instead of Indic text.</div></div>
</div>
<p><b>Kashmiri</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><small>English: </small><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="&#39;k&#39; in &#39;kind&#39;">k</span><span title="/æ/: &#39;a&#39; in &#39;bad&#39;">æ</span><span title="/ʃ/: &#39;sh&#39; in &#39;shy&#39;">ʃ</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="&#39;m&#39; in &#39;my&#39;">m</span><span title="/ɪər/: &#39;ear&#39; in &#39;near&#39;">ɪər</span><span title="/i/: &#39;y&#39; in &#39;happy&#39;">i</span></span>/</a></span></span>)<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> or <b>Koshur</b> (Kashmiri: <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">كٲشُر</span></span></span> <span style="font-size:85%;">(<a href="/wiki/Perso-Arabic" class="mw-redirect" title="Perso-Arabic">Perso-Arabic</a></span>, <span style="font-size:85%;"><a href="/wiki/Official_scripts_of_the_Republic_of_India" title="Official scripts of the Republic of India">Official Script</a>)</span>&#160;; <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1177148991">.mw-parser-output .IPA-label-small{font-size:85%}.mw-parser-output .references .IPA-label-small,.mw-parser-output .infobox .IPA-label-small,.mw-parser-output .navbox .IPA-label-small{font-size:100%}</style><span class="IPA-label IPA-label-small">Kashmiri pronunciation:</span> <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="ks-Latn-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA" title="Help:IPA">&#91;kəːʃur&#93;</a></span>)<sup id="cite_ref-e26_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-e26-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> is a <a href="/wiki/Dardic_languages" title="Dardic languages">Dardic</a> <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_languages" title="Indo-Aryan languages">Indo-Aryan language</a> spoken by around 7 million <a href="/wiki/Kashmiris" title="Kashmiris">Kashmiris</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Kashmir_region" class="mw-redirect" title="Kashmir region">Kashmir region</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> primarily in the <a href="/wiki/Kashmir_Valley" title="Kashmir Valley">Kashmir Valley</a> of the Indian-administrated <a href="/wiki/Union_territory" title="Union territory">union territory</a> of <a href="/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(union_territory)" title="Jammu and Kashmir (union territory)">Jammu and Kashmir</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> Kashmiri has <a href="/wiki/Split_ergativity" title="Split ergativity">split ergativity</a> and the unusual <a href="/wiki/V2_word_order" title="V2 word order">verb-second word order</a>.
</p><p>Since 2020, It has been made an official language of <a href="/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(union_territory)" title="Jammu and Kashmir (union territory)">Jammu and Kashmir</a> along with <a href="/wiki/Dogri" class="mw-redirect" title="Dogri">Dogri</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindi" title="Hindi">Hindi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a> and English.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> Kashmiri is also among the 22 <a href="/wiki/Languages_with_official_status_in_India" title="Languages with official status in India">scheduled languages</a> of India. 
</p><p>Kashmiri is spoken by roughly five percent of Pakistan-Administrated <a href="/wiki/Azad_Kashmir" title="Azad Kashmir">Azad Kashmir</a>'s population.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> It has close relationship with other Indo-Aryan languages, especially <a href="/wiki/Punjabi_Language" class="mw-redirect" title="Punjabi Language">Standard Punjabi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lahnda" title="Lahnda">Western Punjabi</a>, Sindhi, and the dialects of Western Pahari. <sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<meta property="mw:PageProp/toc" />
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geographic_distribution_and_status">Geographic distribution and status</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Geographic distribution and status"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>There are about 6.8 million speakers of Kashmiri and related dialects in Jammu and Kashmir and amongst the <a href="/wiki/Kashmiri_diaspora" title="Kashmiri diaspora">Kashmiri diaspora</a> in other states of India.<sup id="cite_ref-Census2011_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census2011-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> Most Kashmiri speakers are located in the <a href="/wiki/Kashmir_Valley" title="Kashmir Valley">Kashmir Valley</a> and other areas of Jammu and Kashmir.<sup id="cite_ref-Koshur_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Koshur-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> In the Kashmir valley, they form a majority.
</p><p>Kashmiri is spoken by roughly five percent of <a href="/wiki/Azad_Kashmir" title="Azad Kashmir">Azad Kashmir</a>'s population.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/1998_Pakistan_Census" class="mw-redirect" title="1998 Pakistan Census">1998 Pakistan Census</a>, there were 132,450 Kashmiri speakers in Azad Kashmir.<sup id="cite_ref-Shakil2_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Shakil2-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> Native speakers of the language were dispersed in "pockets" throughout Azad Kashmir,<sup id="cite_ref-Kachru2_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kachru2-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-KJLR2_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KJLR2-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup> particularly in the districts of <a href="/wiki/Muzaffarabad_District" title="Muzaffarabad District">Muzaffarabad</a> (15%), <a href="/wiki/Neelum_District" title="Neelum District">Neelam</a> (20%) and <a href="/wiki/Hattian_Bala_District" title="Hattian Bala District">Hattian</a> (15%), with very small minorities in <a href="/wiki/Haveli_District" title="Haveli District">Haveli</a> (5%) and <a href="/wiki/Bagh_District" title="Bagh District">Bagh</a> (2%).<sup id="cite_ref-Shakil2_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Shakil2-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> The Kashmiri spoken in Muzaffarabad is distinct from, although still <a href="/wiki/Mutual_intelligibility" title="Mutual intelligibility">intelligible</a> with, the Kashmiri of the Neelam Valley to the north.<sup id="cite_ref-KJLR2_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KJLR2-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup> In Neelam Valley, Kashmiri is the second most widely spoken language and the majority language in at least a dozen or so villages, where in about half of these, it is the sole mother tongue.<sup id="cite_ref-KJLR2_21-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KJLR2-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup>  The Kashmiri dialect of Neelum is closer to the variety spoken in northern Kashmir Valley, particularly <a href="/wiki/Kupwara_district" title="Kupwara district">Kupwara</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-KJLR2_21-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KJLR2-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/2017_Census_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="2017 Census of Pakistan">2017 Census of Pakistan</a>, as many as 350,000 people declared their first language to be Kashmiri.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>A process of <a href="/wiki/Language_shift" title="Language shift">language shift</a> is observable among Kashmiri-speakers in Azad Kashmir according to linguist <a href="/wiki/Tariq_Rahman" title="Tariq Rahman">Tariq Rahman</a>, as they gradually adopt local dialects such as <a href="/wiki/Pahari-Pothwari" title="Pahari-Pothwari">Pahari-Pothwari</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindko" title="Hindko">Hindko</a> or move towards the <i>lingua franca</i> <a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Kachru2_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kachru2-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-KJLR2_21-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KJLR2-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup> This has resulted in these languages gaining ground at the expense of Kashmiri.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup> There have been calls for the promotion of Kashmiri at an official level; in 1983, a Kashmiri Language Committee was set up by the government to patronise Kashmiri and impart it in school-level education. However, the limited attempts at introducing the language have not been successful, and it is Urdu, rather than Kashmiri, that Kashmiri Muslims of <a href="/wiki/Azad_Kashmir" title="Azad Kashmir">Azad Kashmir</a> have seen as their identity symbol.<sup id="cite_ref-Rahman2_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rahman2-28">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> Rahman notes that efforts to organise a Kashmiri language movement have been challenged by the scattered nature of the Kashmiri-speaking community in Azad Kashmir.<sup id="cite_ref-Rahman2_28-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rahman2-28">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Kashmiri language is one of the <a href="/wiki/Languages_with_official_status_in_India" title="Languages with official status in India">22 scheduled languages</a> of <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Central_Institute_of_Indian_Languages_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Central_Institute_of_Indian_Languages-29">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup> It was a part of the <i>eighth Schedule</i> in the former constitution of the Jammu and Kashmir. Along with other regional languages mentioned in the <i>Sixth Schedule</i>, as well as Hindi and Urdu, the Kashmiri language was to be developed in the state.<sup id="cite_ref-GAD_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GAD-30">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup> After <a href="/wiki/Hindi" title="Hindi">Hindi</a>, Kashmiri is the second fastest growing <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_India" title="Languages of India">language of India</a>, followed by <a href="/wiki/Meitei_language" title="Meitei language">Meitei</a> (<a href="/wiki/Manipuri_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Manipuri language">Manipuri</a>) as well as <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_language" title="Gujarati language">Gujarati</a> in the third place, and <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali</a> in the fourth place, according to the <a href="/wiki/2011_census_of_India" title="2011 census of India">2011 census of India</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Persian began to be used as the court language in Kashmir during the 14th centuries, under the influence of Islam. It was replaced by Urdu in 1889 during the <a href="/wiki/Dogra_dynasty" title="Dogra dynasty">Dogra rule</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup> In 2020, Kashmiri became an official language in the Union Territory of <a href="/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(Union_Territory)" class="mw-redirect" title="Jammu and Kashmir (Union Territory)">Jammu and Kashmir</a> for the first time.<sup id="cite_ref-OfficialLang_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OfficialLang-34">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Poguli" class="mw-redirect" title="Poguli">Poguli</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kishtwari" title="Kishtwari">Kishtwari</a> are closely related to Kashmiri, which are spoken in the mountains to the south of the Kashmir Valley and have sometimes been counted as dialects of Kashmiri.
</p><p>The people in the <a href="/wiki/Chenab_Valley" title="Chenab Valley">Chenab region</a> of Indian-administered Jammu and Kashmir mainly speak Kashmiri, but the accent and various words differentiate it from the Kashmiri spoken in the Kashmir Valley. <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Chenab_Times&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Chenab Times (page does not exist)">The Chenab Times</a>, a news outlet known for promoting lesser-known languages, has termed this language as <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Chenabi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chenabi (page does not exist)">Chenabich Kashir</a>,</i> meaning <i>the Kashmiri language spoken in Chenab Valley.</i><sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Phonology">Phonology</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Phonology"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Kashmiri has the following phonemes.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali20069–16_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali20069–16-39">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Vowels">Vowels</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Vowels"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The oral vowels are as follows: 
</p>
<dl><dd><table class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;">

<tbody><tr>
<th>&#160;
</th>
<th><a href="/wiki/Front_vowel" title="Front vowel">Front</a>
</th>
<th><a href="/wiki/Central_vowel" title="Central vowel">Central</a>
</th>
<th><a href="/wiki/Back_vowel" title="Back vowel">Back</a>
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th><a href="/wiki/Close_vowel" title="Close vowel">High</a>
</th>
<td><span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Close_front_unrounded_vowel" title="Close front unrounded vowel">i</a></span> <span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Close_front_unrounded_vowel" title="Close front unrounded vowel">iː</a></span>
</td>
<td><span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Close_central_unrounded_vowel" title="Close central unrounded vowel">ɨ</a></span> <span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Close_central_unrounded_vowel" title="Close central unrounded vowel">ɨː</a></span>
</td>
<td><span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Close_back_rounded_vowel" title="Close back rounded vowel">u</a></span> <span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Close_back_rounded_vowel" title="Close back rounded vowel">uː</a></span>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th><a href="/wiki/Mid_vowel" title="Mid vowel">Mid</a>
</th>
<td><span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Close-mid_front_unrounded_vowel" title="Close-mid front unrounded vowel">e</a></span> <span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Close-mid_front_unrounded_vowel" title="Close-mid front unrounded vowel">eː</a></span></td>
<td><span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Mid_central_vowel" title="Mid central vowel">ə</a></span> <span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Mid_central_vowel" title="Mid central vowel">əː</a></span>
</td>
<td><span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Close-mid_back_rounded_vowel" title="Close-mid back rounded vowel">o</a></span> <span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Close-mid_back_rounded_vowel" title="Close-mid back rounded vowel">oː</a></span>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th><a href="/wiki/Open_vowel" title="Open vowel">Low</a>
</th>
<td>
</td>
<td><span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Open_front_unrounded_vowel" title="Open front unrounded vowel">a</a></span> <span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Open_front_unrounded_vowel" title="Open front unrounded vowel">aː</a></span></td>
<td><span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Open-mid_back_rounded_vowel" title="Open-mid back rounded vowel">ɔ</a></span> <span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Open-mid_back_rounded_vowel" title="Open-mid back rounded vowel">ɔː</a></span>
</td></tr></tbody></table></dd></dl>
<p>The short high vowels are <a href="/wiki/Near-high_vowel" class="mw-redirect" title="Near-high vowel">near-high</a>, and the low vowels apart from <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">/aː/</span> are <a href="/wiki/Near-low_vowel" class="mw-redirect" title="Near-low vowel">near-low</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Nasalization" title="Nasalization">Nasalization</a> is phonemic. All sixteen oral vowels have nasal counterparts.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Consonants">Consonants</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Consonants"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>

<td><span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Voiceless_alveolar_fricative" title="Voiceless alveolar fricative">s</a></span>
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td><span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Voiceless_postalveolar_fricative" title="Voiceless postalveolar fricative">ʃ</a></span>
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td><span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Voiceless_glottal_fricative" title="Voiceless glottal fricative">h</a></span>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th><span style="font-size:85%;"><a href="/wiki/Voice_(phonetics)" title="Voice (phonetics)">voiced</a></span>
</th>
<td>
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td><span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Voiced_alveolar_fricative" title="Voiced alveolar fricative">z</a></span>
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th colspan="2"><a href="/wiki/Approximant_consonant" class="mw-redirect" title="Approximant consonant">Approximant</a>
</th>
<td><span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Voiced_labial%E2%80%93velar_approximant" title="Voiced labial–velar approximant">w</a></span>
</td>
<td><span class="IPA" lang="und-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Voiced_dental_lateral_approximant" class="mw-redirect" title="Voiced dental lateral approximant">l</a></span>
</td>
<td>

<td>

</td>

</th>
<td>

</td>

</td>

</td>
<td>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><a href="/wiki/Palatalization_(phonetics)" title="Palatalization (phonetics)">Palatalization</a> is phonemic. All consonants apart from those in the post-alveolar/palatal column have palatalized counterparts.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Archaisms">Archaisms</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Archaisms"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Kashmiri, as also the other Dardic languages, shows important divergences from the Indo-Aryan mainstream. One is the partial maintenance of the three <a href="/wiki/Sibilant" title="Sibilant">sibilant consonants</a> <i>s ṣ ś</i> of the Old Indo-Aryan period. For another example, the prefixing form of the number 'two', which is found in Sanskrit as <i>dvi-</i>, has developed into <i>ba-/bi-</i> in most other Indo-Aryan languages, but <i>du-</i> in Kashmiri (preserving the original dental stop <i>d</i>). <i>Seventy-two</i> is <i>dusatath</i> in Kashmiri, <i>bahattar</i> in Hindi-Urdu and Punjabi, and <i>dvisaptati</i> in Sanskrit.<sup id="cite_ref-ref41yomid_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ref41yomid-40">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Certain features in Kashmiri even appear to stem from Indo-Aryan even predating the Vedic period. For instance, there was an /s/ &gt; /h/ consonant shift in some words that had already occurred with Vedic Sanskrit (This tendency was complete in the Iranian branch of Indo-Iranian), yet is lacking in Kashmiri equivalents. The word <i>rahit</i> in Vedic Sanskrit and modern Hindi-Urdu (meaning 'excluding' or 'without') corresponds to <i>rost</i> in Kashmiri. Similarly, <i>sahit</i> (meaning 'including' or 'with') corresponds to <i>sost</i> in Kashmiri.<sup id="cite_ref-ref41yomid_40-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ref41yomid-40">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Writing_system">Writing system</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Writing system"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1129693374"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1045330069">.mw-parser-output <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span style="font-size: 125%; line-height: 170%;"> <span class="Nastaliq" dir="rtl" title="Nastaliq" style="font-family: &#39;Jameel Noori href="/wiki/%D8%B2" class="mw-redirect" title="ز">ز</a> <a href="/wiki/%DA%98" class="mw-redirect" title="ژ">ژ</a> <a href="/wiki/%D8%B3" class="mw-redirect" title="س">س</a> <a href="/wiki/%D8%B4" title="ن">ن</a> (<a href="/wiki/%DA%BA" class="mw-redirect" title="ں">ں</a>) <a href="/wiki/%D9%88" class="mw-redirect" title="و">و</a> <a href="/wiki/%DB%86" class="mw-redirect" title="ۆ">ۆ</a> <a href="/wiki/%DB%84" class="mw-redirect" title="ۄ">ۄ</a> <a href="/wiki/%DA%BE" class="mw-redirect" title="ھ">ھ</a> <a href="/wiki/%D8%A1" class="mw-redirect" title="ء">ء</a> <a href="/wiki/%DB%8C" class="mw-redirect" title="ی">ی</a> <a href="/wiki/%D8%A0" class="mw-redirect" title="ؠ">ؠ</a> <a href="/wiki/%DB%92" class="mw-redirect" title="ے">ے</a> </span>   </span></span></span></td>
</tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading">
<hr /><a href="/wiki/Arabic_script" title="Arabic script">Arabic script</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content hlist">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Arabic_alphabet" title="History of the Arabic alphabet">History</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Transliteration_of_Arabic" class="mw-redirect" title="Transliteration of Arabic">Transliteration</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Arabic_diacritics" title="Arabic diacritics">Diacritics</a>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Hamza" title="Hamza">Hamza</a></li></ul></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Eastern_Arabic_numerals" title="Eastern Arabic numerals">Numerals</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Abjad_numerals" title="Abjad numerals">Numeration</a></li></ul></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1129693374"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1063604349">.mw-parser-output .navbar{display:inline;font-size:88%;font-weight:normal}.mw-parser-output .navbar-collapse{float:left;text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .navbar-boxtext{word-spacing:0}.mw-parser-output .navbar ul{display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap;line-height:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::before{margin-right:-0.125em;content:"[ "}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::after{margin-left:-0.125em;content:" ]"}.mw-parser-output .navbar li{word-spacing:-0.125em}.mw-parser-output .navbar a>span,.mw-parser-output .navbar a>abbr{text-decoration:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-mini abbr{font-variant:small-caps;border-bottom:none;text-decoration:none;cursor:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-full{font-size:114%;margin:0 7em}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-mini{font-size:114%;margin:0 4em}</style><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Arabic-script_sidebar" title="Template:Arabic-script sidebar"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Arabic-script_sidebar" title="Template talk:Arabic-script sidebar"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a href="/wiki/Special:EditPage/Template:Arabic-script_sidebar" title="Special:EditPage/Template:Arabic-script sidebar"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>There are three <a href="/wiki/Orthography" title="Orthography">orthographical systems</a> used to write the Kashmiri language: the <a href="/wiki/Perso-Arabic_script" class="mw-redirect" title="Perso-Arabic script">Perso-Arabic script</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Devanagari_script" class="mw-redirect" title="Devanagari script">Devanagari script</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sharada_script" title="Sharada script">Sharada script</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Roman_script" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman script">Roman script</a> is also sometimes informally used to write Kashmiri, especially online.<sup id="cite_ref-Mouton_de_Gruyter_4-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mouton_de_Gruyter-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Today Kashmiri is primarily written in Perso-Arabic (with some modifications).<sup id="cite_ref-Omniglot-Kashmiri_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Omniglot-Kashmiri-41">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup> Among languages written in the Perso-Arabic script, Kashmiri is one of the scripts that regularly indicates all vowel sounds.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Kashmiri Perso-Arabic script is recognized as the official script of Kashmiri language by the Jammu and Kashmir government and the <a href="/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_Academy_of_Art,_Culture_and_Languages" title="Jammu and Kashmir Academy of Art, Culture and Languages">Jammu and Kashmir Academy of Art, Culture and Languages</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup> The Kashmiri Perso-Arabic script has been derived from <a href="/wiki/Persian_alphabet" title="Persian alphabet">Persian alphabet</a>. The consonant inventory and their corresponding pronounciations of Kashmiri Perso-Arabic script doesn't differ from Perso-Arabic script, with the exception of the letter <a href="/wiki/%C5%BDe" title="Že">ژ</a>, which is pronounced as <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">/<a href="/wiki/Voiceless_alveolar_affricate" title="Voiceless alveolar affricate">t͡s</a>/</span> instead of <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">/<a href="/wiki/Voiced_postalveolar_fricative" title="Voiced postalveolar fricative">ʒ</a>/</span>. However, the vowel inventory of Kashmiri is significantly larger than other Perso-Arabic derived or influenced South Asian Perso-Arabic scripts. There are 17 vowels in Kashmiri, shown with <a href="/wiki/Arabic_diacritics" title="Arabic diacritics">diacritics</a>, letters (<a href="/wiki/Aleph" title="Aleph">alif</a>, <a href="/wiki/Waw_(letter)" title="Waw (letter)">waw</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yodh" title="Yodh">ye</a>), or both. In Kashmiri, the convention is that most vowel diacritics are written at all times.
</p><p>Despite Kashmiri Perso-Arabic script cutting across religious boundaries and being used by both the <a href="/wiki/Kashmiri_Hindus" title="Kashmiri Hindus">Kashmiri Hindus</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Kashmiri_Muslims" title="Kashmiri Muslims">Kashmiri Muslims</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup> some attempts have been made to give a religious outlook regarding the script and make Kashmiri Perso-Arabic script to be associated with <a href="/wiki/Kashmiri_Muslims" title="Kashmiri Muslims">Kashmiri Muslims</a>, while the Kashmiri Devanagari script to be associated with some sections of <a href="/wiki/Kashmiri_Hindus" title="Kashmiri Hindus">Kashmiri Hindu</a> community.<sup id="cite_ref-Indian_Express-Perso-Arabic_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Indian_Express-Perso-Arabic-48">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-KOA-Devanagari_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KOA-Devanagari-49">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Kashmiri language was traditionally written in the <a href="/wiki/Sharada_script" title="Sharada script">Sharada script</a> after the 8th Century A.D.<sup id="cite_ref-Sharada_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sharada-51">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup> The script grew increasingly unsuitable for writing Kashmiri because it couldn't adequately represent Kashmiri peculiar sounds by the usage of its vowel signs.<sup id="cite_ref-sharada_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sharada-52">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup> Therefore, it is not in common use today and is restricted to religious ceremonies of the <a href="/wiki/Kashmiri_Pandit" class="mw-redirect" title="Kashmiri Pandit">Kashmiri Pandits</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-KOA-Sharada_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KOA-Sharada-53">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Perso-Arabic_script">Perso-Arabic script</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Perso-Arabic script"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Consonants_2">Consonants</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Consonants"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>

<td style="white-space:nowrap"><span style="font-size:80%;">  <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;"> ألِف </span></span></span></span><br /><i>ạlif</i>

</td>

<td><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">ـیـ / یـ</span></span></span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">بیـ / ـبیـ / ریـ</span></span></span>
</td>
<td><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">ایـ / اے </span></span></span>
</td>
<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[eː]</span>
</td>
<td><i>ē</i>
</td>

</td>
<td><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">ریش</span></span></span><br /><small>rēsh</small>
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>Beard
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="white-space:nowrap"><span style="font-size:80%;">  <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;"> گول یایُک</span></span></span></span><br /><i>gōl yāyuk</i>

<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Vowels_3">Vowels</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Vowels"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>There have been a few versions of the Devanagari script for Kashmiri.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup>
The 2002 version of the proposal is shown below.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup> This version has readers and more content available on the Internet, even though this is an older proposal.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup> 
This version makes use of the vowels ॲ/ऑ and vowel signs
कॅ/कॉ for the schwa-like vowel <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[ə]</span> and elongated schwa-like vowel <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[əː]</span> that also exist in other Devanagari-based scripts such as Marathi and Hindi but are used for the sound of other vowels.
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Letter
</th>
<td><b><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">अ</span></span></b></td>
<td><b><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">आ</span></span></b></td>
<td><b>ॲ</b></td>
<td><b><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">ऑ</span></span></b>
</td>
<td><b><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">इ</span></span></b></td>
<td><b><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">ई</span></span></b></td>
<td><b><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">ॶ</span></span></b>
</td>
<td><b><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">ॷ</span></span></b></td>
<td><b><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">उ</span></span></b></td>
<td><b><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">ऊ</span></span></b></td>
<td><b><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">ऎ</span></span></b></td>
<td><b><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">ए</span></span></b>
</td>
<td><b><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">ऐ</span></span></b></td>
<td><b><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">ऒ</span></span></b></td>
<td><b><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">ओ</span></span></b></td>
<td><b><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">औ</span></span></b></td>
<td><b><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">-व</span></span></b></td>
<td><b><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">ँ</span></span></b>

<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[ə]</span></td>

</td>

<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[iː]</span></td>
<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[ɨ]</span>

<td><i>ai</i></td>
<td><i>o</i></td>
<td><i>ō</i></td>
<td><i>ọ̄</i></td>
<td><i>ọ</i></td>
<td><i> ̃</i>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>Vowel mark indicated on consonant <i>k</i>
</th>
<td><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">क</span></span>
</td>
<td><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">का</span></span>
</td>
<td><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">कॅ</span></span>
</td>
<td><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">कॉ</span></span>
</td>
<td><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">कि</span></span>
</td>
<td><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">की</span></span>
</td>
<td><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">कॖ</span></span>
</td>
<td><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">कॗ</span></span>
</td>
<td><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">कु</span></span>
</td>
<td><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">कू</span></span>
</td>
<td><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">कॆ</span></span>
</td>
<td><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">के</span></span>
</td>
<td><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">कै</span></span>
</td>
<td><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">कॊ</span></span>
</td>
<td><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">को</span></span>
</td>
<td><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">कौ</span></span>
</td>
<td><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">क्व</span></span> <i>or</i> <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">कव</span></span>
</td>
<td><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">कं</span></span>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Tabulated below is the latest (2009) version of the proposal to spell the Kashmiri vowels with Devanagari.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup> 
The primary change in this version is the changed stand alone characters ॳ / ॴ and vowel signs <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">कऺ</span></span> / <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">कऻ</span></span> for the schwa-like vowel <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[ə]</span> &amp; elongated schwa-like vowel <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[əː]</span> and a new stand alone vowel <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">ॵ</span></span> and vowel sign <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks-Deva">कॏ</span></span> for the open-mid back rounded vowel <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[ɔ]</span> which can be used instead of the consonant व standing-in for this vowel.
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>

<th>Isolated glyph
</th>
<th>Remarks<sup id="cite_ref-unicode.org_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unicode.org-71">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup>
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1009416381"><span class="script-Shrd" style="font-size:16px; line-height:2.1em;">𑆑𑆾𑆮𑇀 𑆑</span>

</td>
<td>

</td></tr>

<td>

</td>
<td>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1009416381"><span class="script-Shrd" style="font-size:16px; line-height:2.1em;">𑆝𑆑 𑆞</span>

<td><i>ḍaka ḍhạ</i>
</td>
<td><i>ḍha</i>
</td>
<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[ɖʰa]</span>
</td>
<td><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1009416381"><span class="script-Shrd" style="font-size:16px; line-height:2.1em;">𑆞</span>
</td>
<td>The Kashmiri Language does not possess this consonant.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1009416381"><span class="script-Shrd" style="font-size:16px; line-height:2.1em;">𑆤𑆳𑆤𑆓𑆶𑆫𑆴 𑆟</span>

<td>The Kashmiri Language does not possess this vowel.
</td></tr>

<td><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1009416381"><span class="script-Shrd" style="font-size:16px; line-height:2.1em;">𑆬𑆵𑆪𑆮𑇀 𑆌</span>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Grammar">Grammar</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Grammar"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Kashmiri is a <a href="/wiki/Fusional_language" title="Fusional language">fusional language</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200625_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200625-73">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup> with <a href="/wiki/V2_word_order" title="V2 word order">verb-second (V2)</a> word order.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup> Several of Kashmiri's grammatical features distinguish it from other <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_languages" title="Indo-Aryan languages">Indo-Aryan languages</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali2006ii_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali2006ii-75">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nouns">Nouns</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Nouns"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Kashmiri nouns are inflected according to gender, number and case. There are no <a href="/wiki/Article_(grammar)" title="Article (grammar)">articles</a>, nor is there any grammatical distinction for <a href="/wiki/Definiteness" title="Definiteness">definiteness</a>, although there is some optional adverbial marking for indefinite or "generic" noun qualities.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200625_73-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200625-73">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Gender">Gender</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Gender"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>The Kashmiri <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_gender" title="Grammatical gender">gender</a> system is divided into masculine and feminine. Feminine forms are typically generated by the addition of a suffix (or in most cases, a <a href="/wiki/Morphophonology" title="Morphophonology">morphophonemic</a> change, or both) to a masculine noun.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200625_73-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200625-73">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup> A relatively small group of feminine nouns have unique <a href="/wiki/Suppletion" title="Suppletion">suppletion</a> forms that are totally different from the corresponding masculine forms.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200628_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200628-76">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup> The following table illustrates the range of possible gender forms:<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200626–28_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200626–28-77">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup>	
</p>
<dl><dd><dl><dd><table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<th>Process</th>
<th>Masculine</th>
<th>Feminine</th>
<th>Meaning
</th></tr>








<tr>
<td>Adding of affix
</td>
<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[huːn]</span>
<p><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">ہوٗن</span></span></span>
</p>
</td>
<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[huːnʲ]</span>
<p><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">ہوٗنؠ</span></span></span>
</p>

</td></tr>

<td>feminine only</td>

<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[mət͡ʃʰ]</span>
<p><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">مٔچھ</span></span></span>
</p>
</td>
<td>housefly
</td></tr></tbody></table></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>Some nouns borrowed from other languages, such as Persian, Arabic, Sanskrit, Urdu or English, follow a slightly different gender system. Notably, many words borrowed from Urdu have different genders in Kashmiri.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200628_76-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200628-76">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Case">Case</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Case"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>There are five <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_case" title="Grammatical case">cases</a> in Kashmiri: <a href="/wiki/Nominative_case" title="Nominative case">nominative</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dative_case" title="Dative case">dative</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ergative_case" title="Ergative case">ergative</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ablative_case" title="Ablative case">ablative</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vocative_case" title="Vocative case">vocative</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200631_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200631-78">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup> Case is expressed via suffixation of the noun.
</p><p>Kashmiri utilizes an <a href="/wiki/Ergative-absolutive_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Ergative-absolutive language">ergative-absolutive case structure</a> when the verb is in simple past tense.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200631_78-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200631-78">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup> Thus, in these sentences, the <a href="/wiki/Subject_(grammar)" title="Subject (grammar)">subject</a> of a <a href="/wiki/Transitive_verb" title="Transitive verb">transitive verb</a> is marked in the ergative case and the <a href="/wiki/Object_(grammar)" title="Object (grammar)">object</a> in nominative, which is identical to how the subject of an <a href="/wiki/Intransitive_verb" title="Intransitive verb">intransitive verb</a> is marked.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200631_78-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200631-78">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWade188816_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWade188816-79">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup> However, in sentences constructed in any other tense, or in past tense sentences with intransitive verbs, a nominative-dative paradigm is adopted, with objects (whether direct or indirect) generally marked in dative case.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200632_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200632-81">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Other case distinctions, such as <a href="/wiki/Locative_case" title="Locative case">locative</a>, <a href="/wiki/Instrumental_case" title="Instrumental case">instrumental</a>, <a href="/wiki/Genitive_case" title="Genitive case">genitive</a>, <a href="/wiki/Comitative_case" title="Comitative case">comitative</a> and <a href="/wiki/Allative_case" title="Allative case">allative</a>, are marked by <a href="/wiki/Preposition_and_postposition" title="Preposition and postposition">postpositions</a> rather than suffixation.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200639_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200639-82">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Noun_morphology">Noun morphology</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Noun morphology"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>The following table illustrates Kashmiri noun declension according to gender, number and case.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200632_81-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200632-81">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWade188810–15_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWade188810–15-83">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

</td></tr></tbody></table></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Verbs">Verbs</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Verbs"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Kashmiri verbs are declined according to tense and <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_person" title="Grammatical person">person</a>, and to a lesser extent, gender. Tense, along with certain distinctions of <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_aspect" title="Grammatical aspect">aspect</a>, is formed by the addition of suffixes to the verb stem (minus the <a href="/wiki/Infinitive" title="Infinitive">infinitive</a> ending - /un/), and in many cases by the addition of various <a href="/wiki/Modal_verb" title="Modal verb">modal auxiliaries</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200683–84_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200683–84-84">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup> Postpositions fulfill numerous adverbial and semantic roles.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali2006119_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali2006119-85">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Tense">Tense</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Tense"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Present tense in Kashmiri is an auxiliary construction formed by a combination of the <a href="/wiki/Copula_(linguistics)" title="Copula (linguistics)">copula</a> and the imperfective suffix -/aːn/ added to the verb stem. The various copula forms agree with their subject according to gender and number, and are provided below with the verb /jun/ (to come):<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200684_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200684-86">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup>	
</p>
<dl><dd><dl><dd><table class="wikitable">
<caption>Present
</caption>
<tbody><tr>
<th>
</th>
<th>Masculine
</th>
<th>Feminine
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th>1st Person Sing.
</th>

<th>3rd Person Pl.
</th>
<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[t͡ʃʰi<span class="wrap"> </span>jiwaːn]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">چھِ یِوان</span></span></span>
</td>
<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[t͡ʃʰe<span class="wrap"> </span>jiwaːn]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks" dir="rtl">چھےٚ یِوان</span></span>
</td></tr></tbody></table></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>Past tense in Kashmiri is significantly more complex than the other tenses, and is subdivided into three past tense distinctions.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200686_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200686-87">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup> The simple (sometimes called proximate) past refers to completed past actions. Remote past refers to actions that lack this in-built perfective aspect. Indefinite past refers to actions performed a long time ago, and is often used in historical narrative or storytelling contexts.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200687_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200687-88">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>As described above, Kashmiri is a <a href="/wiki/Split_ergativity" title="Split ergativity">split-ergative</a> language; in all three of these past tense forms, the subjects of transitive verbs are marked in the ergative case and direct objects in the nominative. Intransitive subjects are marked in the nominative.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200687_88-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200687-88">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup> Nominative arguments, whether subjects or objects, dictate gender, number and person marking on the verb.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200687_88-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200687-88">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Verbs of the simple past tense are formed via the addition of a suffix to the verb stem, which usually undergoes certain uniform morphophonemic changes. First and third person verbs of this type do not take suffixes and agree with the nominative object in gender and number, but there are second person verb endings. The entire simple past tense paradigm of transitive verbs is illustrated below using the verb /parun/ ("to read"):<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200689–90_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200689–90-90">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[pərwɨ]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">پٔروٕ</span></span></span>
</td>
<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[pariwɨ]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">پَرِوٕ</span></span></span>

<tr>
<th colspan="2">3rd Person
</th>
<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[por]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">پۆر</span></span></span>
</td>
<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[pərʲ]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">پٔرؠ</span></span></span>
</td>
<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[pər]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">پٔر</span></span></span>
</td>
<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[pari]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">پَرِ</span></span></span>
</td></tr></tbody></table></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>A group of irregular intransitive verbs (<i>special intransitives</i>), take a different set of endings in addition to the morphophonemic changes that affect most past tense verbs.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200691–92_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200691–92-91">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<p>Intransitive verbs in the simple past are conjugated the same as intransitives in the indefinite past tense form.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200693_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200693-92">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<td>-<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[jeːjakʰ]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">یے یَکھ</span></span></span>
</td>
<td>-<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[jeːjiwɨ]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">یے یِوٕ</span></span></span>
</td></tr>

<th>3rd Person
</th>
<td>-<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[joːw]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">یوو</span></span></span>

</td>
<td>-<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[jeːji]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">یے یہِ</span></span></span>
</td>
<td>-<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[jeːji]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">یے یہِ</span></span></span>
</td></tr></tbody></table></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>In contrast to the simple past, verb stems are unchanged in the indefinite and remote past, although the addition of the tense suffixes does cause some morphophonetic change.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200694_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200694-93">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup> Transitive verbs are declined according to the following paradigm:<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200694–95_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200694–95-94">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<p>As in the simple past, "special intransitive" verbs take a different set of endings in the indefinite and remote past:<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200696–97_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200696–97-95">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
