<td>-<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[eːjaːjɨ]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">ے یایہٕ</span></span></span>
</td>
<td>-<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[eːjaːjɨ]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">ے یایہٕ</span></span></span>
</td></tr></tbody></table></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>Regular intransitive verbs also take a different set of endings in the indefinite and remote past, subject to some morphophonetic variation:<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200696–99_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200696–99-96">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<th>3rd Person
</th>
<td>-<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[jeːjoːw]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">یے یوو</span></span></span>
</td>
<td>-<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[jeːji]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">یے یہِ</span></span></span>
</td>
<td>-<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[jeːjaːjɨ]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">یے یایہٕ</span></span></span>
</td>
<td>-<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[jeːjɨ]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">یے یہٕ</span></span></span>
</td></tr></tbody></table></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>Future tense intransitive verbs are formed by the addition of suffixes to the verb stem:<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali2006100–101_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali2006100–101-97">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<th>3rd Person

</td>
<td>-<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[an]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">اَن</span></span></span>
</td></tr></tbody></table></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>The future tense of transitive verbs, however, is formed by adding suffixes that agree with both the subject and direct object according to number, in a complex fashion:<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali2006103_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali2006103-98">&#91;91&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

</td></tr></tbody></table></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Aspect">Aspect</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Aspect"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>There are two main <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_aspect" title="Grammatical aspect">aspectual</a> distinctions in Kashmiri, perfective and imperfective. Both employ a <a href="/wiki/Participle" title="Participle">participle</a> formed by the addition of a suffix to the verb stem, as well as the fully conjugated auxiliary /aːsun/ ("to be")—which agrees according to gender, number and person with the object (for transitive verbs) or the subject (for intransitive verbs).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali2006105_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali2006105-99">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Like the auxiliary, the participle suffix used with the <b>perfective</b> aspect (expressing completed or concluded action) agrees in gender and number with the object (for transitive verbs) or subject (for intransitives) as illustrated below:<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali2006105_99-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali2006105-99">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dd><dl><dd><table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<th rowspan="2">
</th>
<th colspan="2">Masculine
</th>

</th></tr>

<tr>
<td>
</td>
<td>-<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[mut]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">مُت</span></span></span>
</td>
<td>-<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[mɨtʲ]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">مٕتؠ</span></span></span>
</td>
<td>-<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[mɨt͡s]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">مٕژ</span></span></span>
</td>
<td>-<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[mat͡sɨ]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">مَژٕ</span></span></span>
</td></tr></tbody></table></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>The <b>imperfective</b> (expressing habitual or progressive action) is simpler, taking the participle suffix -/aːn/ in all forms, with only the auxiliary showing agreement.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali2006107_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali2006107-100">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup> A type of <a href="/wiki/Iterative_aspect" title="Iterative aspect">iterative aspect</a> can be expressed by <a href="/wiki/Reduplication" title="Reduplication">reduplicating</a> the imperfective participle.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali2006108_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali2006108-101">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pronouns">Pronouns</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Pronouns"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Pronoun" title="Pronoun">Pronouns</a> are declined according to person, gender, number and case, although only third person pronouns are overtly gendered. Also in third person, a distinction is made between three degrees of proximity, called proximate, remote I and remote II.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200653_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200653-102">&#91;95&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dd><dl><dd><table class="wikitable">
<caption>Nominative
</caption>

<th colspan="2">Feminine
</th></tr>

<tr>
<th>remote II
</th>

</td>
<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[tǝmi]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">تٔمہِ</span></span></span>
</td>
<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[timaw]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">تِمَو</span></span></span>
</td></tr></tbody></table></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>There is also a dedicated genitive pronoun set, in contrast to the way that the genitive is constructed adverbially elsewhere. As with future tense, these forms agree with both the subject and direct object in person and number.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200652_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200652-103">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dd><dl><dd><table class="wikitable">

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Adjectives">Adjectives</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Adjectives"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>There are two kinds of adjectives in Kashmiri, those that agree with their referent noun (according to case, gender and number) and those that are not declined at all.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup> Most adjectives are declined, and generally take the same endings and gender-specific stem changes as nouns.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWade188819_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWade188819-105">&#91;98&#93;</a></sup> The declinable adjective endings are provided in the table below, using the adjective /wɔzul/ ("red"):<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWade188820_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWade188820-106">&#91;99&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200659_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200659-107">&#91;100&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dd><dl><dd><table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<th rowspan="2">
</th>
<th colspan="2">Masculine
</th>
<th colspan="2">Feminine
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th>singular</th>
<th>plural
</th>
<th>singular</th>
<th>plural
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th>Nom.
</th>

<th>Abl.
</th>

</td>
<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[wɔzd͡ʒi]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">وۄزجہِ</span></span></span>
</td>
<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[wɔzd͡ʒaw]</span><br /><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">وۄزجَو</span></span></span>
</td></tr></tbody></table></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>Among those adjectives not declined are adjectives that end in -lad or -a, adjectives borrowed from other languages, and a few isolated irregulars.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWade188820_106-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWade188820-106">&#91;99&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The comparative and superlative forms of adjectives are formed with the words <i>tsor</i> ("more") and <i>sitha</i> ("most"), respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWade188821_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWade188821-108">&#91;101&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Numerals">Numerals</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Numerals"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Within the Kashmir language, numerals are separated into <a href="/wiki/Cardinal_numbers" class="mw-redirect" title="Cardinal numbers">cardinal numbers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ordinal_numbers" class="mw-redirect" title="Ordinal numbers">ordinal numbers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200664_109-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200664-109">&#91;102&#93;</a></sup> These numeral forms, as well as their aggregative (both, all the five, etc.), <a href="/wiki/Multiplicative_numerals" class="mw-redirect" title="Multiplicative numerals">multiplicative</a> (two times, four times, etc.), and emphatic forms (only one, only three, etc.) are provided by the table below.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200664_109-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoulWali200664-109">&#91;102&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dd><dl><dd><table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<td></td>
<td><b>Cardinal</b></td>
<td><b>Ordinal</b></td>
<td><b>Aggregative</b></td>
<td><b>Multiplicative</b></td>
<td><b>Emphatic</b>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><b>Suffix</b></td>
<td>&#160;</td>
<td>-<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[jum]</span> for masculine
<p>-<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[im]</span> for feminine
</p>
</td>
<td>-[waj]</td>
<td>-<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[ɡun]</span> or -<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[ɡon]</span> for masculine
<p>-<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[ɡɨn]</span> for feminine
</p>
</td>
<td> -[j]
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><b>0.</b>
</td>
<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[sifar]</span>
<p><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">صِفَر</span></span></span>

<tr>
<td><b>1.</b></td>
<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[akʰ]</span>
<p><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">اَکھ</span></span></span>

<p><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks" dir="rtl">أکیُٛم</span></span> or <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks" dir="rtl">أکِم</span></span>
</p>
</td>
<td>&#160;</td>
<td>&#160;<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[oɡun]</span> or <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[oɡɨn]</span>
<p><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">اۆگُن</span></span></span> or <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">اۆگٕن</span></span></span>
</p>

<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[akuj]</span>

<td><b>42.</b>

<td><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[arɨhəːʈʰjum]</span> or <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[arɨhəːʈʰim]</span>

<p><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks" dir="rtl">دٔہ لَچھیُٛم</span></span> or <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks" dir="rtl">داہ لَچھیُٛم</span></span>

</p>

<td><b>Ten million</b>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Vocabulary">Vocabulary</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Vocabulary"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Kashmiri is an <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-Aryan language">Indo-Aryan language</a> and was heavily influenced by <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>, especially early on.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">&#91;104&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Gorekar2002_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gorekar2002-113">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup> After the arrival of <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquests_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="Muslim conquests in the Indian subcontinent">Islamic administrative rule in India</a>, Kashmiri acquired many <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a> loanwords.<sup id="cite_ref-Gorekar2002_113-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gorekar2002-113">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup> In modern times, Kashmiri vocabulary has imported words from
<a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindustani_language" title="Hindustani language">Hindustani</a> and <a href="/wiki/Punjabi_language" title="Punjabi language">Punjabi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Preservation_of_old_Indo-Aryan_vocabulary">Preservation of old Indo-Aryan vocabulary</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Preservation of old Indo-Aryan vocabulary"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Kashmiri retains several features of <a href="/wiki/Old_Indo-Aryan" class="mw-redirect" title="Old Indo-Aryan">Old Indo-Aryan</a> that have been lost in other modern Indo-Aryan languages such as Hindi-Urdu, Punjabi and Sindhi.<sup id="cite_ref-ref41yomid_40-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ref41yomid-40">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup> Some vocabulary features that Kashmiri preserves clearly date from the <a href="/wiki/Vedic_Sanskrit" title="Vedic Sanskrit">Vedic Sanskrit</a> era and had already been lost even in Classical Sanskrit. This includes the word-form <i>yodvai</i> (meaning <i>if</i>), which is mainly found in Vedic Sanskrit texts. Classical Sanskrit and modern Indo-Aryan use the word <i>yadi</i> instead.<sup id="cite_ref-ref41yomid_40-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ref41yomid-40">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="First_person_pronoun">First person pronoun</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: First person pronoun"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Both the Indo-Aryan and Iranian branches of the Indo-Iranian family have demonstrated a strong tendency to eliminate the distinctive first person pronoun ("I") used in the nominative (subject) case. The <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-European_pronouns" title="Proto-Indo-European pronouns">Indo-European root</a> for this is reconstructed as *eǵHom, which is preserved in Sanskrit as <i>aham</i> and in Avestan Persian as <i>azam</i>. This contrasts with the <i>m-</i> form ("me", "my") that is used for the accusative, genitive, dative, ablative cases. Sanskrit and Avestan both used forms such as <i>ma(-m)</i>. However, in languages such as Modern Persian, Baluchi, Hindi and Punjabi, the distinct nominative form has been entirely lost and replaced with <i>m-</i> in words such as <i>ma-n</i> and <i>mai</i>. However, Kashmiri belongs to a relatively small set that preserves the distinction. 'I' is <i>ba/bi/bo</i> in various Kashmiri dialects, distinct from the other <i>me</i> terms. 'Mine' is <i>myon</i> in Kashmiri. Other Indo-Aryan languages that preserve this feature include <a href="/wiki/Dogri" class="mw-redirect" title="Dogri">Dogri</a> (<i>aun</i> vs <i>me-</i>), <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_language" title="Gujarati language">Gujarati</a> (<i>hu-n</i> vs <i>ma-ri</i>), <a href="/wiki/Konkani_language" title="Konkani language">Konkani</a> (<i>hā̃v</i> vs <i>mhazo</i>), and <a href="/wiki/Braj_Bhasa" class="mw-redirect" title="Braj Bhasa">Braj</a> (<i>hau-M</i> vs <i>mai-M</i>). The Iranian <a href="/wiki/Pashto_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Pashto language">Pashto</a> preserves it too (<i>za</i> vs. <i>maa</i>), as well as <a href="/wiki/Nuristani_languages" title="Nuristani languages">Nuristani languages</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Askunu_language" title="Askunu language">Askunu</a> (<i>âi</i> vs <i>iũ</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-ref48bubag_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ref48bubag-115">&#91;108&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Variations">Variations</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Variations"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>There are very minor differences between the Kashmiri spoken by Hindus and Muslims.<sup id="cite_ref-ref16muduc_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ref16muduc-116">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup> For 'fire', a traditional Hindu uses the word <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">اۆگُن</span></span></span> <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[oɡun]</span> while a Muslim more often uses the Arabic word <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">نار</span></span></span> <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[naːr]</span>.<sup id="cite_ref-Kasref_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kasref-117">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sample_text">Sample text</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Sample text"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Perso-Arabic_script_2">Perso-Arabic script</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Perso-Arabic script"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Art. 1 of the <a href="/wiki/Universal_Declaration_of_Human_Rights" title="Universal Declaration of Human Rights">Universal Declaration of Human Rights</a>:
</p><p><span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;"> سٲری اِنسان چھِ آزاد زامٕتؠ۔ وؠقار تہٕ حۆقوٗق چھِ ہِوی۔ تِمَن چھُ سوچ سَمَج عَطا کَرنہٕ آمُت تہٕ تِمَن پَزِ بٲے بَرادٔری ہٕنٛدِس جَذباتَس تَحَت اَکھ أکِس اَکار بَکار یُن ۔</span></span></span> <sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">&#91;111&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[səːriː<span class="wrap"> </span>insaːn<span class="wrap"> </span>t͡ʃʰi<span class="wrap"> </span>aːzaːd<span class="wrap"> </span>zaːmɨtʲ<span class="wrap"> </span>.<span class="wrap"> </span>wʲakaːr<span class="wrap"> </span>tɨ<span class="wrap"> </span>hokuːk<span class="wrap"> </span>t͡ʃʰi<span class="wrap"> </span>hiwiː<span class="wrap"> </span>.<span class="wrap"> </span>timan<span class="wrap"> </span>t͡ʃʰu<span class="wrap"> </span>soːt͡ʃ<span class="wrap"> </span>samad͡ʒ<span class="wrap"> </span>ataː<span class="wrap"> </span>karnɨ<span class="wrap"> </span>aːmut<span class="wrap"> </span>tɨ<span class="wrap"> </span>timan<span class="wrap"> </span>pazi<span class="wrap"> </span>bəːj<span class="wrap"> </span>baraːdəriː<span class="wrap"> </span>hɨndis<span class="wrap"> </span>d͡ʒazbaːtas<span class="wrap"> </span>tahat<span class="wrap"> </span>akʰ<span class="wrap"> </span>əkis<span class="wrap"> </span>akaːr<span class="wrap"> </span>bakaːr<span class="wrap"> </span>jun]</span>
</p><p>"All human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights. They are endowed with reason and conscience and should act towards one another in a spirit of brotherhood."
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sharada_script_2">Sharada script</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Sharada script"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Verses by <a href="/wiki/Lalleshwari" title="Lalleshwari">Lalleshwari</a>:<b><sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup></b>
</p><p><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1009416381"><span class="script-Shrd" style="font-size:16px; line-height:2.1em;">𑆏𑆩𑆶𑆅 𑆃𑆑𑆶𑆪 𑆃𑆗𑆶𑆫 𑆥𑆾𑆫𑆶𑆩𑇀 𑆱𑆶𑆪𑆲𑆳 𑆩𑆳𑆬𑆴 𑆫𑆾𑆛𑆶𑆩𑇀 𑆮𑆶𑆤𑇀𑆢𑆱𑇀 𑆩𑆁𑆘 𑆱𑆶𑆅 𑆩𑆳𑆬𑆴 𑆑𑆤𑆴 𑆥𑇀𑆪𑆜 𑆓𑆾𑆫𑆶𑆩𑇀 𑆠 𑆖𑆾𑆫𑆶𑆩𑇀 𑆃𑆱𑆱𑇀 𑆱𑆳𑆱 𑆠 𑆱𑆥𑆤𑇀𑆪𑆱 𑆱𑆾𑆤𑇆</span>
</p><p><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[oːmuj<span class="wrap"> </span>akuj<span class="wrap"> </span>at͡ʃʰur<span class="wrap"> </span>porum,<span class="wrap"> </span>suj<span class="wrap"> </span>maːli<span class="wrap"> </span>roʈum<span class="wrap"> </span>wɔndas<span class="wrap"> </span>manz,<span class="wrap"> </span>suj<span class="wrap"> </span>maːli<span class="wrap"> </span>kani<span class="wrap"> </span>pʲaʈʰ<span class="wrap"> </span>gorum<span class="wrap"> </span>tɨ<span class="wrap"> </span>t͡sorum,<span class="wrap"> </span>əːsɨs<span class="wrap"> </span>saːs<span class="wrap"> </span>tɨ<span class="wrap"> </span>sapnis<span class="wrap"> </span>sɔn.]</span>
</p><p>"I kept reciting the unique divine word "Om" and kept it safe in my heart through my resolute dedication and love. I was simply ash and by its divine grace got metamorphosed into gold."
</p><p><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1009416381"><span class="script-Shrd" style="font-size:16px; line-height:2.1em;">𑆃𑆑𑆶𑆪 𑆏𑆀𑆑𑆳𑆫 𑆪𑆶𑆱 𑆤𑆳𑆨𑆴 𑆣𑆫𑆼 𑆑𑆶𑆩𑇀𑆮𑆪 𑆧𑇀𑆫𑆲𑇀𑆩𑆳𑆟𑇀𑆝𑆱 𑆪𑆶𑆱 𑆓𑆫𑆴 𑆃𑆒 𑆩𑆶𑆪 𑆩𑆁𑆠𑇀𑆫 𑆪𑆶𑆱 𑆖𑇀𑆪𑆠𑆱 𑆑𑆫𑆼 𑆠𑆱 𑆱𑆳𑆱 𑆩𑆁𑆠𑇀𑆫 𑆑𑇀𑆪𑆳 𑆑𑆫𑆼𑇆</span>
</p><p><span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[akuj<span class="wrap"> </span>omkaːr<span class="wrap"> </span>jus<span class="wrap"> </span>naːbi<span class="wrap"> </span>dareː,<span class="wrap"> </span>kumbeː<span class="wrap"> </span>brahmaːnɖas<span class="wrap"> </span>sum<span class="wrap"> </span>gareː,<span class="wrap"> </span>akʰ<span class="wrap"> </span>suj<span class="wrap"> </span>mantʰɨr<span class="wrap"> </span>t͡sʲatas<span class="wrap"> </span>kareː,<span class="wrap"> </span>tas<span class="wrap"> </span>saːs<span class="wrap"> </span>mantʰɨr<span class="wrap"> </span>kjaː<span class="wrap"> </span>kareː.]</span>
</p><p>One who recites the divine word "Omkār" by devotion is capable to build a bridge between his own and the cosmic consciousness. By staying committed to this sacred word, one doesn't require any other mantra out of thousands others.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: See also"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1132942124">.mw-parser-output .portalbox{padding:0;margin:0.5em 0;display:table;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:175px;list-style:none}.mw-parser-output .portalborder{border:solid #aaa 1px;padding:0.1em;background:#f9f9f9}.mw-parser-output .portalbox-entry{display:table-row;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;height:1.9em;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portalbox-image{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portalbox-link{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .portalleft{clear:left;float:left;margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portalright{clear:right;float:right;margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}}</style><ul role="navigation" aria-label="Portals" class="noprint portalbox portalborder portalright">
<li class="portalbox-entry"><span class="portalbox-image"><span class="noviewer" typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Quill_and_ink.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="icon" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Quill_and_ink.svg/28px-Quill_and_ink.svg.png" decoding="async" width="28" height="28" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Quill_and_ink.svg/42px-Quill_and_ink.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Quill_and_ink.svg/56px-Quill_and_ink.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="152" data-file-height="152" /></a></span></span><span class="portalbox-link"><a href="/wiki/Portal:Poetry" title="Portal:Poetry">Poetry portal</a></span></li></ul>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Kashmir_Valley" title="Kashmir Valley">Kashmir Valley</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Kashmiri_Wikipedia" title="Kashmiri Wikipedia">Kashmiri Wikipedia</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/List_of_Indian_poets#Kashmiri" title="List of Indian poets">List of Kashmiri poets</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/List_of_topics_on_the_land_and_the_people_of_%E2%80%9CJammu_and_Kashmir%E2%80%9D" class="mw-redirect" title="List of topics on the land and the people of “Jammu and Kashmir”">List of topics on the land and the people of “Jammu and Kashmir”</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Shina_language" title="Shina language">Shina language</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/States_of_India_by_Kashmiri_speakers" title="States of India by Kashmiri speakers">States of India by Kashmiri speakers</a></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Notes"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-upper-alpha">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-56"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-56">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">At the beginning of a word it can either come with diacritic, or it can be stand-alone and silent, succeeded by a vowel letter. Diacritics <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;"> اَ اِ، اُ</span></span></span> can be omitted in writing. Other diacritics (i.e. <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">آ، أ، ٲ، إ، اٟ</span></span></span>) are never omitted. For example, <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">اَخبار</span></span></span> <i>"akhbār"</i> is often written as <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">اخبار</span></span></span>, whereas <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">أچھ</span></span></span> <i>" ȧchh"</i> is never written as <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">اچھ</span></span></span>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-57"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-57">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Used mainly for <a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a> loanwords.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-58"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-58">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The letter <i>wāw</i> can either represent consonant ([w/v]) or vowel ([oː]). It can also act as a carrier of vowel diacritics, representing several other vowels <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">وٗ, ۆ, ۄ</span></span></span> (uː], [o], [ɔ]). At the beginning of a word, when representing a consonant, the letter <i>wāw</i> will appear as a standalone character, followed by the appropriate vowel. If representing a vowel at the beginning of a word, the letter <i>wāw</i> needs to be preceeded by an <i>ạlif</i>, <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">او, اوٗ, اۆ, اۄ</span></span></span>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-59"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-59">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This letter differs from <i>do-chashmi hē</i> (ھ) and they are not interchangeable. Similar to Urdu,<i>do-chashmi hē</i> (ھ) is exclusively used as a second part of <a href="/wiki/Digraph_(orthography)" title="Digraph (orthography)">digraphs</a> for representing <a href="/wiki/Aspirated_consonant" title="Aspirated consonant">aspirated consonants</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-60"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-60">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In initial and medial position, the letter <i>hē</i> always represents the consonant [h]. In final position, The letter <i>hē</i> can either represent consonant ([h]) or vowel ([a]). In final position, only in its attached form, and not in isolated form, it can also act as a carrier of vowel diacritics, representing several other vowels <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">ـٔہ, ـہٕ</span></span></span> ([ə], [ɨ]). For example, whereas a final "-rạ" is written as <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">ـرٔ</span></span></span>, a final "-gạ" is written as <span title="Kashmiri-language text"><span lang="ks"><span class="Nastaliq" style="font-family:&#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Roz Urdu Punjabi Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Emad Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">ـگٔہ</span></span></span>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-61"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-61">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The letter <i>yē</i> can either represent consonant ("y" [j]) or vowel ("ē" [eː] or "ī" [iː]). The letter <i>yē</i> can represent [j] in initial or medial position, or it can represent "ē" [eː] or "ī" [iː] in medial positions, or "ī" [iː] in final position. In combination with specific diacritics, the letter <i>yē</i> in its medial position, can represent "ī" [iː], "e" [e], "ĕ" [ʲa], or ' [◌ʲ] as well. To represent the consonant "y" [j] or the vowel "ē" [eː] in final position, the letter <i>boḍ yē</i> (<span class="Nastaliq" dir="rtl" title="Nastaliq" style="font-family: &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Awami Nastaliq Beta3&#39;, &#39;Awami Nastaliq Beta2&#39;, &#39;Awami Nastaliq Beta1&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">ے</span>) is used. The letter <i>boḍ yē</i> (<span class="Nastaliq" dir="rtl" title="Nastaliq" style="font-family: &#39;Jameel Noori Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Urdu Typesetting&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu&#39;, &#39;Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft&#39;, &#39;Hussaini Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq&#39;, IranNastaliq, &#39;Awami Nastaliq&#39;, &#39;Awami Nastaliq Beta3&#39;, &#39;Awami Nastaliq Beta2&#39;, &#39;Awami Nastaliq Beta1&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01&#39;, &#39;Pak Nastaleeq&#39;, &#39;PDMS_Jauhar&#39;, &#39;Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq&#39;; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">ے</span>), in combination with specific diacritics, can represent "e" [e] in final position.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-62"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-62">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The letter <i>boḍ yē</i> only occurs in final position. The letter <i>boḍ yē</i> represents the consonant "y" [j] or the vowel "ē" [eː]. With specific diacritics, vowel "e" [e] is also shown with the letter <i>boḍ yē</i>.</span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashmiri_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: References"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1011085734"><div class="reflist">
<div class="mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-e26-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-e26_1-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-e26_1-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-e26_1-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.ethnologue.com/language/kas">Kashmiri</a> at <i><a href="/wiki/Ethnologue" title="Ethnologue">Ethnologue</a></i> (26th ed., 2023) <span style="position:relative; top: -2px;"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/Paywall" title="closed access publication – behind paywall"><img alt="Closed access icon" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Closed_Access_logo_transparent.svg/9px-Closed_Access_logo_transparent.svg.png" decoding="async" width="9" height="14" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Closed_Access_logo_transparent.svg/14px-Closed_Access_logo_transparent.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Closed_Access_logo_transparent.svg/18px-Closed_Access_logo_transparent.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="1000" /></a></span></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-Census2011-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Census2011_16-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.censusindia.gov.in/2011Census/Language-2011/Statement-1.pdf">"Abstract of speakers' strength of languages and mother tongues - 2011"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2 July</span> 2018</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Abstract+of+speakers%27+strength+of+languages+and+mother+tongues+-+2011&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.censusindia.gov.in%2F2011Census%2FLanguage-2011%2FStatement-1.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AKashmiri+language" class="Z3988"></span> The precise figures from the 2011 census are 6,554,36 for Kashmiri as a "mother tongue" and 6,797,587 for Kashmiri as a "language" (which includes closely related smaller dialects/languages).</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Koshur-17"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Koshur_17-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.koshur.org/contents.html">"Koshur: An Introduction to Spoken Kashmiri"</a>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2 June</span> 2007</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Koshur%3A+An+Introduction+to+Spoken+Kashmiri&amp;rft.pub=Kashmir+News+Network%3A+Language+Section+%28koshur.org%29&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.koshur.org%2Fcontents.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AKashmiri+language" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-18">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFBukhari2011" class="citation news cs1">Bukhari, Shujaat (14 June 2011). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.thehindu.com/opinion/op-ed/The-other-Kashmir/article13834085.ece">"The other Kashmir"</a>. <i>The Hindu</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-Shakil2-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Shakil2_19-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Shakil2_19-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFShakil2012" class="citation journal cs1">Shakil, Mohsin (2012). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.academia.edu/6485567">"Languages of Erstwhile State of Jammu Kashmir (A Preliminary Study)"</a>. <i>University of Azad Jammu and Kahsmir</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-Kachru2-20"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Kachru2_20-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Kachru2_20-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFKachru2002" class="citation web cs1"><a href="/wiki/Braj_Kachru" title="Braj Kachru">Kachru, Braj B.</a> (3 July 2002). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://koausa.org/language/pdf/DyingLinguistic.pdf">"The Dying Linguistic Heritage of the Kashmiris: Kashmiri Literary Culture and Language"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Kashmiri Overseas Association</i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180619010025/http://koausa.org/language/pdf/DyingLinguistic.pdf">Archived</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> from the original on 19 June 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-KJLR2-21"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-KJLR2_21-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-KJLR2_21-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-KJLR2_21-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-KJLR2_21-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-KJLR2_21-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFAkhtarRehman2007" class="citation journal cs1">Akhtar, Raja Nasim; Rehman, Khawaja A. (2007). "The Languages of the Neelam Valley". <i>Kashmir Journal of Language Research</i>. <b>10</b> (1): 65–84. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.worldcat.org/issn/1028-6640">1028-6640</a>. <q>Additionally, Kashmiri speakers are better able to understand the variety of Srinagar than the one spoken in Muzaffarabad.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Kashmir+Journal+of+Language+Research&amp;rft.atitle=The+Languages+of+the+Neelam+Valley&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=65-84&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.issn=1028-6640&amp;rft.aulast=Akhtar&amp;rft.aufirst=Raja+Nasim&amp;rft.au=Rehman%2C+Khawaja+A.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AKashmiri+language" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-23"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-23">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFSnedden2015" class="citation book cs1">Snedden, Christopher (15 September 2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=a19eCwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PT33"><i>Understanding Kashmir and Kashmiris</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-24">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFKaw2004" class="citation book cs1">Kaw, M. K. (2004). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=QpjKpK7ywPIC&amp;pg=PA328"><i>Kashmir and It's People: Studies in the Evolution of Kashmiri Society</i></a>. APH Publishing. pp.&#160;328–329. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-7648-537-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-7648-537-1"><bdi>978-81-7648-537-1</bdi></a>. <q>In parts of Pakistan, as a Pakistani scholar, Rahman observes (1996:225-226), "there are pockets of Kashmiri-speaking people in Azad Kashmir [Pakistan-occupied Kashmir] and elsewhere ..." Rahman adds that the process of language shift is in progress among Kashmiri speakers in Pakistan too, as: most of the them [Kashmiris] are gradually shifting to other languages such as the local Pahari and Mirpuri which are dialects of Punjabi...Most literate people use Urdu since, in both Azad and Indian-held Kashmir, Urdu rather than Kashmiri is the official language of government.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Kashmir+and+It%27s+People%3A+Studies+in+the+Evolution+of+Kashmiri+Society&amp;rft.pages=328-329&amp;rft.pub=APH+Publishing&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.isbn=978-81-7648-537-1&amp;rft.aulast=Kaw&amp;rft.aufirst=M.+K.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DQpjKpK7ywPIC%26pg%3DPA328&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AKashmiri+language" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-25">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFHockBashir2016" class="citation book cs1">Hock, Hans Henrich; Bashir, Elena (24 May 2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=0iFBDAAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PT811"><i>The Languages and Linguistics of South Asia: A Comprehensive Guide</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-26"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-26">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite class="citation news cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://tribune.com.pk/story/897933/up-north-call-for-exploration-of-archaeological-sites">"Up north: Call for exploration of archaeological sites"</a>. <i>The Express Tribune</i>. 4 June 2015<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-27"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-27">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFKhan2016" class="citation news cs1">Khan, Zafar Ali (20 February 2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://tribune.com.pk/story/1051223/lack-of-preservation-causing-regional-languages-to-die-a-slow-death">"Lack of preservation causing regional languages to die a slow death"</a>. <i>The Express Tribune</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">25 October</span> 2020</span>. <q>Dr Khawaja Abdul Rehman, who spoke on Pahari and Kashmiri, said pluralistic and tolerance-promoting Kashmiri literature was fast dying, as its older generation had failed to transfer the language to its youth. He said that after a few decades, not a single Kashmiri-speaking person will be found in Muzaffarabad...</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Express+Tribune&amp;rft.atitle=Lack+of+preservation+causing+regional+languages+to+die+a+slow+death&amp;rft.date=2016-02-20&amp;rft.aulast=Khan&amp;rft.aufirst=Zafar+Ali&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Ftribune.com.pk%2Fstory%2F1051223%2Flack-of-preservation-causing-regional-languages-to-die-a-slow-death&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AKashmiri+language" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Rahman2-28"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Rahman2_28-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Rahman2_28-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFRahman1996" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Tariq_Rahman" title="Tariq Rahman">Rahman, Tariq</a> (1996). <i>Language and politics in Pakistan</i>. <li id="cite_note-31"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-31">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">—<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.deccanherald.com/india/what-census-data-reveals-about-use-of-indian-languages-738340.html">"What census data reveals about use of Indian languages"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Deccan_Herald" title="Deccan Herald">Deccan Herald</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-ref41yomid-40"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-ref41yomid_40-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ref41yomid_40-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ref41yomid_40-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ref41yomid_40-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFK.L._Kalla1985" class="citation cs2">K.L. Kalla (1985), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=mzozRa9wJ9kC"><i>The Literary Heritage of Kashmir</i></a>, Mittal Publications, <q><i>... Kashmiri alone of all the modern Indian languages preserves the dvi (Kashmiri du) of Sanskrit, in numbers such as dusatath (Sanskrit dvisaptati), dunamat (Sanskrit dvanavatih) ... the latter (Yodvai) is archaic and is to be come across mainly in the Vedas ...</i></q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Literary+Heritage+of+Kashmir&amp;rft.pub=Mittal+Publications&amp;rft.date=1985&amp;rft.au=K.L.+Kalla&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DmzozRa9wJ9kC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AKashmiri+language" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-a-o-70"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-a-o_70-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The central vowels are typically transcribed <span class="nowrap">&#x27e8;ạ&#x27e9;</span> and <span class="nowrap">&#x27e8;u’&#x27e9;</span> when transliterating Arabic script, <span class="nowrap">&#x27e8;ö&#x27e9;</span> and <span class="nowrap">&#x27e8;ü&#x27e9;</span> when transliterating Nagari.</span>

<li id="cite_note-110"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-110">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFToushikhani_S._k" class="citation book cs1">Toushikhani S. k, Koul J. lal. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://archive.org/details/in.ernet.dli.2015.510168"><i>Kashir Dictionary Vol 1</i></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Kashir+Dictionary+Vol+1&amp;rft.aulast=Toushikhani+S.+k&amp;rft.aufirst=Koul+J.+lal&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fin.ernet.dli.2015.510168&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AKashmiri+language" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-111"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-111">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFEggeling1911" class="citation encyclopaedia cs1">Eggeling, Hans Julius (1911). <span class="cs1-ws-icon" title="s:1911 Encyclopædia Britannica/Sanskrit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/1911_Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica/Sanskrit">"Sanskrit"&#160;</a></span>. In <a href="/wiki/Hugh_Chisholm" title="Hugh Chisholm">Chisholm, Hugh</a> (ed.). <i><a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica_Eleventh_Edition" title="Encyclopædia Britannica Eleventh Edition">Encyclopædia Britannica</a></i>. Vol.&#160;24 (11th&#160;ed.). Cambridge University Press. pp.&#160;156–183.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Sanskrit&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft.pages=156-183&amp;rft.edition=11th&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1911&amp;rft.aulast=Eggeling&amp;rft.aufirst=Hans+Julius&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AKashmiri+language" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-112"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-112">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFGrierson1911" class="citation encyclopaedia cs1">Grierson, George Abraham (1911). <span class="cs1-ws-icon" title="s:1911 Encyclopædia Britannica/Kashmiri"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/1911_Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica/Kashmiri">"Kashmiri"&#160;</a></span>. In <a href="/wiki/Hugh_Chisholm" title="Hugh Chisholm">Chisholm, Hugh</a> (ed.). <i><a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica_Eleventh_Edition" title="Encyclopædia Britannica Eleventh Edition">Encyclopædia Britannica</a></i>. Vol.&#160;15 (11th&#160;ed.). Cambridge University Press. pp.&#160;689–693. <q>Sanskrit has been actively studied for many centuries, and the Kashmiri vocabulary, and even its grammar, are now largely Indian. So much is this the case that, for convenience' sake, it is now frequently classed as belonging to the north-western group of languages, instead of as belonging to the Piśāca family as its origin demands. It cannot be said that either classification is wrong.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Kashmiri&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft.pages=689-693&amp;rft.edition=11th&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1911&amp;rft.aulast=Grierson&amp;rft.aufirst=George+Abraham&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AKashmiri+language" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Gorekar2002-113"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Gorekar2002_113-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Gorekar2002_113-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFGorekar2002" class="citation book cs1">Gorekar, Niẓāmuddīn Es (2002). <i>Indo-Islamic Relations</i>. KnowledgeCity Books. p.&#160;67. <q>The Kashmiri language was in the beginning greatly influenced by the Sanskrit language, but with the coming of the Muslims and monarchs like Zainu'l-Abedin it began to accept the influence of Persian which was the language of the rulers.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Indo-Islamic+Relations&amp;rft.pages=67&amp;rft.pub=KnowledgeCity+Books&amp;rft.date=2002&amp;rft.aulast=Gorekar&amp;rft.aufirst=Ni%E1%BA%93%C4%81mudd%C4%ABn+Es&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AKashmiri+language" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-114"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-114">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite class="citation book cs1"><i>Concise Encyclopedia of Languages of the World</i>. Elsevier. 6 April 2010. p.&#160;582. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-08-087775-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-08-087775-4"><bdi>978-0-08-087775-4</bdi></a>. <q>Kashmiri vocabulary can be broadly categorized into Kashmiri/Dardic, Sanskrit, Punjabi, Hindi/Urdu, Persian, and Arabic origins.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Concise+Encyclopedia+of+Languages+of+the+World&amp;rft.pages=582&amp;rft.pub=Elsevier&amp;rft.date=2010-04-06&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-08-087775-4&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AKashmiri+language" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-ref48bubag-115"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ref48bubag_115-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFJohn_D._Bengtson,_Harold_Crane_Fleming2008" class="citation cs2">John D. Bengtson, Harold Crane Fleming (2008), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=xxcdjUGfx40C"><i>In hot pursuit of language in prehistory: essays in the four fields of anthropology</i></a>, John Benjamins Publishing Company, 2008, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-90-272-3252-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-90-272-3252-6"><bdi>978-90-272-3252-6</bdi></a>, <q><i>... However, Gujarati as well as a Dardic language like Kashmiri still preserve the root alternation between subject and non-subject forms (but they replaced the derivative of the Sanskrit subject form ahám by new forms) ...</i></q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=In+hot+pursuit+of+language+in+prehistory%3A+essays+in+the+four+fields+of+anthropology&amp;rft.pub=John+Benjamins+Publishing+Company%2C+2008&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=978-90-272-3252-6&amp;rft.au=John+D.+Bengtson%2C+Harold+Crane+Fleming&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DxxcdjUGfx40C&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AKashmiri+language" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-ref16muduc-116"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ref16muduc_116-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFKeith_Brown,_Sarah_Ogilvie2010" class="citation cs2">Keith Brown, Sarah Ogilvie (6 April 2010), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=F2SRqDzB50wC"><i>Concise encyclopedia of languages of the world</i></a>, Elsevier, 2008, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-08-087774-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-08-087774-7"><bdi>978-0-08-087774-7</bdi></a>, <q><i>... Kashmiri occupies a special position in the Dardic group, being probably the only dardic language that has a written literature dating back to the early 13th century ...</i></q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Concise+encyclopedia+of+languages+of+the+world&amp;rft.pub=Elsevier%2C+2008&amp;rft.date=2010-04-06&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-08-087774-7&amp;rft.au=Keith+Brown%2C+Sarah+Ogilvie&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DF2SRqDzB50wC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AKashmiri+language" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Kasref-117"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Kasref_117-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFKrishna1967" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Gopi_Krishna_(yogi)" title="Gopi Krishna (yogi)">Krishna, Gopi</a> (1967). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160305055908/https://www.scribd.com/doc/7577310/KUNDALINI-the-evolutionary-energy-in-man"><i>Kundalini: The Evolutionary Energy in Man</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-118"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-118">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.ohchr.org/EN/UDHR/Documents/UDHR_Translations/ksh.pdf">"Universal Declaration of Human Rights in Kashmiri Language"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Universal+Declaration+of+Human+Rights+in+Kashmiri+Language&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ohchr.org%2FEN%2FUDHR%2FDocuments%2FUDHR_Translations%2Fksh.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AKashmiri+language" class="Z3988"></span></span>
